sources: trainingforclimbing.com (Hörst) — campus board, weighted pullup, lock-off, uneven grip
_meta.instructions: Two sections: 'updates' patches existing exercises (id + missing fields only), 'new_exercises' are full JSON objects to append. Merge script: only overwrite fields where current value is null, empty list, or empty string.

updates.description: Foundational pull-muscle exercise for climbers. Trains latissimus dorsi, biceps, and scapular stabilizers through full range of motion. Prerequisite for all advanced pulling work — must be able to do 10+ strict reps before progressing to weighted or one-arm variations. (Hörst, Lattice, The Climbing Doctor)
cues: Dead hang start — full elbow extension, shoulders active not passive
Pull elbows DOWN toward pockets, not arms toward bar
Lead with chest, chin clears bar at top
Scapulae depress and retract as you pull — no shrugging
Controlled 2-3s lowering — no dropping

updates.description: Antagonist push exercise for climbers targeting triceps, pectorals, and anterior deltoid. Counterbalances the pull-dominant climbing pattern. Essential for elbow health and pressing strength. (Hörst antagonist training)
cues: Slight forward lean for chest emphasis, upright for triceps
Lower until upper arms are parallel to floor — no deeper
Keep shoulders away from ears throughout
Controlled lowering 2s, no bouncing at bottom
Full lockout at top without hyperextending elbows

updates.description: Foot-on campus board laddering on larger rungs for beginners and intermediate climbers. Trains contact strength and RFD with reduced injury risk. Named after Wolfgang Güllich's original campus board. Entry point to campus training per Hörst: at minimum 2 years experience required.
cues: Feet on wall or holds — use them to stay safe and controlled
Alternate hands smoothly one rung at a time, no skipping
Short, quick movements — eliminate dead time between moves
Engaged shoulders: slightly bent elbows, chest puffed, no shrugging
Stop when form degrades — quality over volume

updates.description: Footless campus board laddering — the core campus training exercise. Develops contact strength (RFD) and explosive finger flexor recruitment. Short reach movements train finger speed; larger rung skips train arm power. (Hörst, Gresham: intermediate-advanced only, 5.12+/V6+ minimum)
cues: Start hanging both hands from bottom rung, elbows slightly bent
Alternate hands in a sprint — minimize contact time on each rung
Keep reaches short to target finger contact strength, not arm power
Chest puffed, shoulders engaged — never shrugged or passive
Stop at first sign of form breakdown — never full crimp

updates.description: Campus board laddering with feet on wall — intermediate progression between foot-on and full footless campus. Reduces load on fingers/tendons while preserving the contact strength stimulus. Ideal entry into campus training. (Hörst, Gresham)
cues: Light foot contact only — weight primarily through arms
Same arm pattern as footless: alternating, quick, short reaches
Gradually reduce foot contribution as strength improves
Focus on explosive hand placement, not foot reliance
Half-crimp grip unless specifically training open-hand

updates.description: One-arm bump sequence on campus board. One hand stays on lower rung while the other bumps as high as possible in rapid succession. Trains unilateral contact strength and deep lock-off simultaneously. Higher RFD stimulus than two-arm laddering. (Hörst, Gresham)
cues: Lower hand locked, upper hand bumps high repeatedly without touching
Go for maximum height per bump — speed and reach combined
Lock-off with lower arm while upper arm catches each bump
Alternate leading hand between sets
3 sets per side, 2-3 min rest — quality over speed

updates.description: Campus board double dyno — both hands release and re-catch simultaneously. Maximum RFD stimulus and coordination demand. Hörst: not recommended until 7b+/V9+ and 5+ years experience. Highest injury risk of all campus exercises. (Hörst, Gresham)
cues: Start mid-board both hands on same rung
Drop to lower rung absorbing with slightly bent elbows — no straight-arm catch
Immediately explode back upward to original rung
Chest up, shoulders engaged throughout the catch
If you miss or straight-arm catch — stop immediately

updates.description: Max-intensity bouldering at or near limit grade for power and technique integration. The most sport-specific way to train power. Problems should be 1-5 moves, requiring near-maximal effort on each attempt. (Hörst, Lattice — primary strength phase exercise)
cues: Problems at ~1-2 moves above flash level
Full rest between attempts: 3-5 min minimum
Focus on specific crux sequences, not volume
Visualize and rest — quality attempts only
Stop session if power clearly dropping

updates.description: Limit bouldering on Kilter Board, Moonboard, or training board. Structured overhanging training with graded problems for quantifiable power development. Board climbing allows repeatable, measurable progress on specific movement patterns. (Lattice, Hörst board training protocols)
cues: Choose problems at limit: ~1-3 move failures expected
Board angle: increase for more power emphasis
Track attempts and progress per problem number
Open-hand or half-crimp; full-crimp only if required by problem
3-5 attempts max per problem before moving on

updates.description: Explosive pull-ups with maximum velocity intent. Trains rate of force development in pull muscles — directly transfers to latching dynamic moves. Key distinction from weighted pull-ups: speed is the load. (Lattice, Hörst power training)
cues: Pull as fast as possible — get chest to bar
Intention is speed, not height of chin
Full dead hang reset between reps — no kipping
3-5 reps max per set while velocity is maintained
If reps slow down — rest longer or end set

updates.description: 4x4 bouldering: 4 problems climbed back-to-back x 4 rounds. Classic power endurance protocol combining anaerobic capacity with skill. Problems at 60-70% max effort for sustainable volume. (Hörst Training for Climbing, widely used in Lattice protocols)
cues: Problems at comfortable flash level — not limit
Rest 3-4 min between rounds, no rest between problems in set
Maintain consistent movement quality across all 4 rounds
Deep pump expected by round 3-4 — breathe through it
Reduce grade if unable to finish all 4 problems in a round

updates.description: Multiple boulder problems linked together without rest. Sustained power endurance training combining intensity and volume. Length: 6-10 problems per link. (Hörst, Lattice power endurance phase)
cues: Choose problems just below flash level for each
Move directly from top of one to base of next
Aim for 8-12 total hard moves per link
Log grade sequence to repeat and progress
Rest 4-5 min between full link circuits

updates.description: Route climbing intervals on rope — repeated ascents of the same route with timed rest. Develops sport-specific power endurance and route reading efficiency. (Hörst threshold training, Lattice route intervals protocol)
cues: Route at ~80% max: should pump but not fail
Rest equal to or less than climb time between reps
Focus on efficient movement and resting on route
Log time per ascent to track improvement
3-5 intervals per session, progressive overload via rest reduction

updates.description: Pull-up with added load (weight belt, vest, or harness) for hypergravity training. Prerequisite: 15+ strict bodyweight pull-ups. Triggers neuromuscular adaptation to higher apparent bodyweight — on removal, bodyweight feels dramatically lighter. (Hörst 5x5 hypergravity protocol)
cues: Add 10-20% bodyweight to start — go up in small increments
Do NOT hang passive in dead hang between reps
Full range: dead hang to chin over bar
4-6 reps per set at 9/10 RPE
Reduce weight or stop if shoulder/elbow pain

updates.description: Pull-up with legs held at 90° (L-sit position). Combines vertical pulling with anterior core isometric demand. Significantly harder than standard pull-up due to lever arm — develops integrated pulling + core tension. (Hörst advanced pull variation)
cues: Achieve L-sit BEFORE initiating pull — not mid-movement
Legs perfectly horizontal, knees and feet together
Pull with same mechanics as standard pull-up
Core braced throughout — back must not arch
Assisted L-sit (band under feet) acceptable for progression

updates.description: Unilateral pull-up variation with one arm extended straight to the side while the other pulls. Bridges gap between two-arm pull-ups and one-arm pull-up. Directly develops lock-off strength and unilateral lat engagement. (Hörst uneven-grip pull-ups, Hooper's Beta OAP progressions)
cues: Wide grip: working arm pulls, straight arm extends laterally
Straight arm PUSHES DOWN as working arm pulls up
Pull until chin is over working hand
Controlled slow lowering — 3s eccentric minimum
Alternate sides, both arms equal volume

updates.description: Isometric hold at multiple pull-up angles (90° and 120°). Trains the specific static strength needed for clipping, resting on routes, and dynamic move setup. Lattice: avoid deep lock-off (>120°) to protect elbows. (Hörst Frenchies protocol base, Lattice lock-off sessions)
cues: Hold at 90°: forearms horizontal — primary position
Hold at 120°: arms more open — secondary position
Never lock off fully closed (bicep on forearm)
Keep shoulders active and depressed throughout
Time under tension: 5-10s per hold, progress duration

updates.description: Assisted one-arm pull-up using towel, band, or pulley system. Primary progression toward one-arm pull-up. Develops unilateral lat and biceps strength. (Hörst uneven-grip protocol, Hooper's Beta 16-level OAP progression)
cues: Use minimum assistance needed to complete the rep with control
2-arm up, shift weight to working arm, 1-arm eccentric down (5s)
The eccentric is the key training stimulus — slow is mandatory
Gradually reduce assistance over weeks
Stop if elbow snaps or sharp pain — reduce load

updates.description: Lateral pull-up traversing from one hand to the other at top position. Trains unilateral pulling and lateral shoulder stability. Directly mimics traversing moves on the wall. (Hooper's Beta, TrainingBeta — advanced pull variation)
cues: Wide grip, pull to top position with both arms
Slide laterally toward one hand until chin over wrist
Slide back through center to the other hand
Keep the non-pulling arm straight but active throughout
Slow and controlled — no swinging or momentum

updates.description: One-arm campus touch — hold bottom rung with both hands, pull up and touch the highest rung possible with one hand using deadpoint technique, return and repeat. Trains maximum unilateral contact strength and explosive reach. (Hörst, Gresham: intermediate-advanced, 5.12+/V6+)
cues: Both hands on low rung, pull up with momentum
Deadpoint the touch: reach at the apex of upward momentum
Touch — don't grab — the high rung, then catch return
Alternate leading hand each rep
Minimum contact time on the catch rung

updates.description: Footless campus laddering with maximum rung spacing — skipping rungs for power. Shifts training emphasis from contact strength to explosive pulling power. (Hörst: larger holds + rung skips = arm power vs small holds + no skips = contact strength)
cues: Larger rungs, skip 1-2 rungs per move
Explosive pull to generate height before placing next hand
Shoulders engaged throughout — never passive hanging
3 sets, 2-3 min rest — stop before form fails
Elite only: do not add weight without 2+ years campus experience

updates.description: Both-hands simultaneous campus board movement — both hands release and land on new rungs at the same time. Maximum coordination and RFD stimulus. Highest contact strength and power demand of all campus exercises. (Hörst, Gresham — advanced only)
cues: Start hands staggered: one high, one low, shoulder-width apart
Simultaneously release and swap positions in one explosive move
Open-hand grip only — never full crimp on catches
Land with bent elbows to absorb force
Rest 3+ min between sets — CNS demanding
